sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.Domai.keywords: Enum DecoderType Enumeration to define the type of a decoder. Namespace : Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.DomainModel.Devices.Monitors Assembly : Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.DomainModel.dll Syntax public enum DecoderType Fields Name Description AutoDetect Detects the decoder automatically. BarcoMonitorWall A decoder of type Barco Monitor Wall. VideoJet10 A decoder of type Video Jet 10. VideoJet1000 A decoder of type Video Jet 1000. VideoJetDecoder3000 A decoder of type VideoJet Decoder 3000. VideoJetDecoder7000 A decoder of type VideoJet Decoder 7000. VideoJetDecoder8000 A decoder of type VideoJet Decoder 8000. Vip10 A decoder of type VIP 10. VipX1600XFAudio A decoder of type VIPX1600XF Audio. VipXd A decoder of type VipXD. VipXdAudio A decoder of type VipXD Audio. VipXdhd A decoder of type VIP XDHD.

api/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.API.h.title: Namespace Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.API | BVMS UI Automation
api/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.API.h.keywords: Namespace Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.API Classes ConfigurationClient Page Object to wrap the Configuration Client of BVMS. ConfigurationManager Manages the Configuration . Devices The central entry point in API to manage the devices. LogicalTree Abstraction of the LogicalTree. Resource Base class for a resource. Schedules Page object for the schedules tab. Interfaces IConfigurationManager Manages the Configuration . IDevices Abstraction to manage devices. IExceptionDaysScheduleTable Manages the recording schedules for exception days. IHolidaysScheduleTable Manages the recording schedules for holidays. ILogicalTree Abstraction of the LogicalTree. IResourceManager Manages the resources. ISchedules Page object for the schedules tab. IWeekdaysScheduleTable Manages the recording schedules for weekdays.

sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.D.title: Namespace Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.Devices | BVMS UI Automation
sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.D.keywords: Namespace Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.Devices Classes AddDeviceDialog<T> Base class for dialogs which appears during creation of a device. AddDeviceDialogConfig<T> Configuration properties for dialog which is used to add a new Device<T> . ContextMenuManager Manager to handle context menus. DeviceDialog<T> Base class for all dialogs which are related to devices. DeviceDialogConfig<T> Configuration properties for a dialog which is used to configure Device<T> . DeviceManager A DeviceManager handles how a device is added, modified and removed in the UI. Depending upon the type of a device some devices appear as own nodes in the DeviceTree and others only as a table in the right pane. Therefore very distinct UI approaches are necessary to access and manage these devices. DevicesPageObject Page Object for the DeviceTree and belonging pane at right side. EditDeviceDialog<T> Configuration properties for a dialog which is used to modify the settings of a Device<T> . PaneDeviceManager A PaneDeviceManager is used to manage Device<T> s which are not handled as a separate node in the DeviceTree. Instead they are handled at the right side of the ConfigClient by selecting their belonging DeviceType node in the DeviceTree (e.g. enterprise Server ). TreeDeviceManager A TreeDeviceManager handles how a Device<T> s, which appears as own nodes in the DeviceTree, have to be managed. Usually it covers the calling of context sensitive menus and showing related dialog.

wiki/Patterns.html.title: Overview about typical used patterns | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/Patterns.html.keywords: Overview about typical used patterns GOF Pattern Template Method In class libraries with similar sibling classes the Template Method pattern is often seen. It allows to define in the parent class a common overall logic, where the individual steps could be adjusted regarding the needs in the derived classes. In the sample AddDevice is the Template Method which defines three steps. The middle step AddDeviceCore should allow the derived classes to implement its own logic. So this step can be defined as abstract or virtual to allow overriding. public class ParentClass { ... public void AddDevice(IDevice device) { DoSomethingBefore(); AddDeviceCore(device); DoSomethingAfter(); } protected abstract void AddDeviceCore(IDevice device); ... In the subclass now AddDeviceCore needs to be implemented. public class ParentClass { ... protected override void AddDeviceCore(IDevice device) { DecoderType.Value = device.DecoderName; ... } ... One other thing is to remark here. In the typical case, that only one step needs to be adjusted, the overridable method is named like the calling method with the suffix Core . Page Object Pattern To follow a the Single Responsibility Principle (see article "Page Object Pattern in Automated Testing"), allow easier navigation and understanding we use partial classes to separate the diverse facets of the page object pattern. The suffix in the *.cs file name reflects the intention. So a source file which names contains ElementMap contains only the logic to interact with the UI elements which we like to access - mostly the logic to find the UI element in the parent UI container. See also Developer Tree to get an understanding how these partial classes parts are organized. Summaries of the content behind the references (stated at the end of this section) Page Object: wraps all elements, actions and validations happening on a page in one single object There's an argument here that the name "page object" is misleading because it makes you think you should have just one page object per page. Something like "panel object" would be better - but the term "page object" is what's become accepted Model user behavior not user interfaces Think Page Components/Fragments, not Page Objects Keep business logic out of your Page Objects; a cleaner approach is to make Page Object classes responsible for doing a single job: locating elements on the page. Encapsulate interaction logic inside step methods, Keep step methods in action classes and use action classes to model user tasks Split into dedicated classes (SRP) Page Object Element Map: Contains all element properties and their location logic Page Object Validator: Consists of the validations that will be performed on the page Page Object (SearchEngineMainPage): Holds the actions that can be performed on the page like Search and Navigate. Exposes an easy access to the Page Validator through the Validate() method. The best implementations of the pattern hide the usage of the Element Map, wrapping it through all action methods UI Tests (SearchEngineTests): This class contains a group of tests related to the above page; it can hold only a single instance of the page object basic rule of thumb for a page object should allow a software client to do anything and see anything that a human can provide an interface that's easy to program to and hides the underlying widgetry in the window should encapsulate the mechanics required to find and manipulate the data in the gui control itself if you navigate to another page, the initial page object should return another page object for the new page (should return the a page object for the next page) Examples: to access a text field: you should have accessor methods that take and return a string check boxes: should use booleans buttons: should be represented by action oriented method names References PluralSight course " Automating UI Tests for WPF Applications ", notably module "Building a Domain-specific Framework" and video "The architecture of the Domain-specific Framework" Page Objects that Suck Less  Tips for writing more maintainable Page Objects Page Object Pattern in Automated Testing PageObject Keep Your Page Objects DRY Advanced Page Object Pattern with Page Fragments Getting Started with Page Object Pattern

wiki/NoticeableProblems.html.title: Noticeable Problems | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/NoticeableProblems.html.keywords: Noticeable Problems Misleading naming the name of the UI elements doesn't fit to the usage hard to navigate through list of UI elements Sample: dialog "Add iSCSI Device" under pool Element Name Automation-ID Usage Network address tbUserName textbox for the user name iSCSI device type passord textbox for the password Name networkAdress textbox for the network address `` name textbox for the device name Sample: Configuration Pane for a Pool Element Name Automation-ID Usage Block reservation for downtime (days) cbLoadbalancingMode combobox for the recording preference NumericUpDown nuDistributionDuration reservation time for blocks Modal Window from Modal Window scanning for encoders starts a window with a progress bar the scanning stops by around 75% and a new modal dialog with scan-status appears this dialog has the progress window as the parent tried to get array of modal window from main window, but the new dialog is not listed inside instead it appears inside the array of modal windows from the scan window

wiki/DevTree.html.keywords: Developer Tree Folders at highest level Folder what's in & Intention .paket artifacts of our dependency management toolset named Paket cfg configuration items data sample data and data sets to play around (in case the data are important, consider to move to cfg ) doc documentation for the project, please read the section Documentation packages extracted packages and temporary artifacts from Paket (not included into repository) paket-files temporary artifacts from Paket (not included into repository) src the source or solution tree containing the source code Solution The src -folder (aka solution tree) is the developer`s main part of the project. It consists of these projects: DomainModel Contains the (UI-)Domain classes of the Configuration Client DomainModel.Tests Unit tests to test the DomainModel Utils Contains some helper classes and extensions. Utils.Tests Unit tests to test the helper classes and extensions. ConfigClient.Sdk This project could be treated as an internal SDK for test developers to interact with UI elements (abstracts the UI). ConfigClient.Sdk.Tests Unit tests for ConfigClient.Sdk ConfigClient.Api API for high level interaction with the Config Client to address use cases. ConfigClient.Api.Tests Unit tests to test the API correctness as well as the entry point for automatic Use Case tests in the context of complete workflows driving the API OpClient.Sdk This project could be treated as an internal SDK for test developers to interact with UI elements (abstracts the UI) of the Operation Client . OpClient.Sdk.Tests Unit tests for OpClient.Sdk OpClient.Api API for high level interaction with the Operation Client to address use cases. OpClient.Api.Tests Unit tests to test the API correctness as well as the entry point for automatic Use Case tests in the context of complete workflows driving the API Sdk.Commons Shared functionalities for the ConfigClient and OpClient projects at SDK level UseCaseTests Test to cover complete end to end use cases between Config Client and Operation Client ConfigClient.ExcelAdapter The ExcelAdapter is the bridge to configure the Config Client via an Excel sheet. ConfigClient.ConsoleApp The runner to instantiate the ExcelAdapter . AutomationElements Contains enhanced or new UI AutomationElements compared to the FlaUI project, for instance the Spinner control. The distinction between the SDK and the API is the level of abstraction. SDK abstracts the UI, API abstracts an use case. To add a device it is one call in the API ( Add Device ) but it needs different steps of the UI which are triggered via the SDK ( Activate Device Pane , Select the device type in tree , setup the device properties ). Documentation see also Documentation The doc -folder contains the project`s documentation. This documentation is built upon a Git sub-module to reference the project Wiki (sub-folder wiki ) artifacts to configure the DocFX documentation system and temporary output from it (sub-folders sdk , api sdk-api ) a Git sub-module with the static web-sites for the hosting platform (sub-folder _site ) Organizing Partial Classes see also Overview about typical used patterns: Page Object Pattern to bundle all belonging class parts ( <PageObject>.ElementMap.cs under one main node in the Solution Explorer we use the the tag <DependentUpon> in a *.csproj file the edit needs to be done manually with an editor like Notepad++ Sample for organizing partial classes In the follow sample AddVrmDialog.ElementMap.cs contains the ElementMap part of the AddVrmDialog class. This entry needs to get enhanced with the <DependentUpon> element referencing the "main" part of the class. the default entry: <Compile Include="Devices\Recorders\AddVrmDialog.cs" /> <Compile Include="Devices\Recorders\AddVrmDialog.ElementMap.cs" /> needs to get modified to: <Compile Include="Devices\Recorders\AddVrmDialog.cs" /> <Compile Include="Devices\Recorders\AddVrmDialog.ElementMap.cs"> <DependentUpon>AddVrmDialog.cs</DependentUpon> </Compile>

sdk-api/index.html.title: Welcome to the BVMS UI Automation API | BVMS UI Automation
sdk-api/index.html.keywords: Welcome to the BVMS UI Automation API This is the reference documentation for the BVMS UI Automation SDK and BVMS UI Automation SDK . To get an overview about the project you can read the project Wiki on Azure DevOps . Additionally this project Wiki is also included in this new DocFX based documentation here .

wiki/SMM.html.title: Software Maintenance Manual | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/SMM.html.keywords: Software Maintenance Manual Get the Sources current URL: git@ssh.dev.azure.com:v3/pas4/Bvms.UiAutomation/Bvms.UiAutomation use option -recursive to clone the Git repository with sub modules see also Documentation Prerequisites Environment Variables During unit testing the Configuration Client and the Operator Client needs to be started. Hence the unit test needs to know where the executables are located. In case they are not in the default location ( %ProgramFiles%\Bosch\.. ) or the credentials are not the default credentials (user is Admin and password is empty) it needs environment variables to overwrite the default settings. ConfigClient.Path , OperatorClient.Path folder where the ConfigClient.exe and OperatorClient.exe are located in ConfigClient.Args , OperatorClient.Args arguments to run the applications (e.g. -user "admin" -password "" ) For developing there are these ways to use these environment variables: Set the environment variables permanent Open dialog System Properties by running sysdm.cpl On tab Advanced click button Environment Variables... to open dialog Environment Variables Set up environment variables ConfigClient.Path , OperatorClient.Path , ConfigClient.Args , OperatorClient.Args as wanted Close dialogs with buttons OK After rebooting the machine these settings become valid Change environment variables temporary for an individual Visual Studio session Open the Developer Command Prompt for Visual Studio Set the environment variables as wanted, e.g. SET "ConfigClient.Path=C:\_projects\tfs\BVMS\Dev\bin\" SET "ConfigClient.Args=-user "admin" -password """ Start Visual Studio with devenv.exe Troubleshooting to verify the current value of an environment variable use ECHO %Variable% e.g. ECHO %ConfigClient.Path%

wiki/Architecture.html.title: Architecture Overview | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/Architecture.html.keywords: Architecture Overview Main Classes Devices All devices have one common property - that is the name of the device. Depending on the device type a device is listed in the DeviceTree on the left side or a pane on the right side. All devices are derived from IDevice and Device . DeviceManager To add and/or configure a device it is necessary to know how the device needs to be added. Some devices are added by using a context-sensitive menu at the device type node in the tree others are added via a button in the pane. A DeviceManager is responsible to handle that logic for a specific device. That means each device needs a corresponding and individual DeviceManager. All these DeviceManagers are subclasses of DeviceManager . AddDeviceDialog During adding a device, most devices need some details specified via a dialog. These dialogs are subclasses of a class generic AddDeviceDialog<T> where T : IDevice . All devices with needs further details captured via a dialog, should derive from AddDeviceDialog<T> and implement the necessary individual logic.

wiki/Documentation.html.title: Documentation | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/Documentation.html.keywords: Documentation Introduction The documentation for the BVMS UI Automation project is provided in a modern and state of the art model. It is based on these sources and perspectives: XML Comments this is the in-source XML-based code documentation with triple slash ( /// <summary>...</summary> ). Wiki which is hosted on Azure DevOps and based on MarkDown as the markup language and Git as the storage to interact with. It is located here: Wiki for BVMS UI Automation To keep the documentation parts as most as possible together we use the technique of Git sub-modules. Git sub-modules allow a Git ("main") repository to reference other ("sub") repositories. This gives the possibility to divide a project into several containers (e.g. because of different life cycle or usage needs) but bundle them together at a top level. In our concrete case we had to include two Git sub-modules BVMS UI Automation project Wiki this Wiki is a Git repository itself containing the MarkDown wiki pages DocFX based Online documentation GitHub Pages allow easily to host (static) web sites. These web sites have to be provided in a (dedicated) Git repository. So the output of DocFX (the static web sites) are committed to this Git repository and then pushed to the remote ( github.io ). Advice: To clone a Git repository together with its sub-modules use the option --recursive Folder structure The DevTree's doc -folder contains the project`s documentation itself and the configuration files for DocFX to process the content. The content and intention in detail: folder doc itself artifacts to configure the DocFX documentation system docfx-json the DocFX project file toc.yml the table of content file to hook up the wiki-pages index.md the landing page for the DocFX generated online documentation sub-folder wiki this is the repository of the Git sub-module from BVMS UI Automation project Wiki it was included via Gits submodule sub-command git submodule add git@ssh.dev.azure.com:v3/<organization>/<project>/<repository>.wiki doc/wiki sub-folder sdk contains the metadata for the SDK part of the documentation extracted from projects ConfigClient.DomainModel and ConfigClient.Sdk sub-folder api contains the metadata for the API part of the documentation extracted from projects ConfigClient.Api and ConfigClient.ConsoleApp sub-folder sdk-api artifacts to configure the DocFX documentation system merges content based on SDK and API metadata together sub-folder _site this is the repository of the Git sub-module with the static web-sites as an output of DocFX the repository is connected to the web site hosting platform (e.g. github.io as a remote) git submodule add git@<alias>:<username>/<username>.github.io.git doc/_site DocFX To process the content of these sources we use DocFX which is the successor of SHFB (Sandcastle Help File Builder). DocFX is platform-agnostic and runs perfectly also under .NET Core. DocFX creates static web-sites which can easily hosted somewhere. To update the documentation these steps are essential: Update the working tree to the latest stand of the Wiki content Extract the XML metadata of the source code (the XML comment) with DocFX Process the documentation input with DocFX to create static web sites as output Commit the output of DocFX to the "online documentation" repository connected to hoster Push this "online documentation" repository Follow the next sections to do that: Update the working tree Open Git Bash in/with sub-folder .../doc/wiki/ Run command git fetch to get the latest stand into your local repository Run command git status to ensure that nothing is uncommitted and the local and remote branch are at the latest stand the output should be something like: Your branch is up to date with 'origin/wikiMaster'. if not: stop further processing and first commit changes, rebase, ... Run command Git pull --ff-only to get the latest stand in your working tree Extract the XML metadata & process the documentation input For the following steps the DocFX toolset needs to be installed on your machine. Use Chocolatey with choco install docfx Open Command Prompt in/with sub-folder .../doc/ Run command docfx metadata doc\docfx.json -o doc to extract the metadata of the source code Run command docfx build .\doc\docfx.json to create the static web-sites Publish the updated documentation To have the updated documentation online available the repository containing the static web-pages must be updated and pushed. Open Git Bash in/with sub-folder .../doc/_site_/ Run command git commit -am "update DocFX documentation" to commit the changes Run command git push to update the remote

wiki/Guidelines.html.title: Guidelines | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/Guidelines.html.keywords: Guidelines Table of Contents Naming Page Object how to name the classes and parts of it Branches naming the Git branches Naming Page Object see also Pattern: Page Object Pattern page objects (aka page components/fragments) should contain a partial class (with suffix ElementMap ) containing the access to UI elements as private properties these properties must (or must not?) end with the UI element type (e.g. private TextBox ServerNameTextBox ) Todo: clarify what better is (must or must not?) data input to page objects must follow the Fluent Interface design principle (must have for creational fashion!) data input must/should? be done via methods having the prefix Set to facilitate the fluent utilization ( fooDialog.SetPassword("p").SetUsername("u").SetPasswordShowing(false) ) Todo: clarify must/should Branches default branches: develop common branch to share information; similar to Main in TFVC master we don't care now; but important in the future; don't use it yet individual/feature/realization branches follow this scheme [branch-type]/[user-identification]/[backlog-item-number]/[context] , where: branch type could be one of the following values: feat realize a backlog-item spike play around with new stuff, prototype new ideas dev under consideration; might be meaningful in case where we don't have a PBI which could be referenced user-identification is the prefix of the Bosch identifier (e.g. mue for Erika Mustermann [backlog-item-number] is the ID of that backlog item [context] short name of the backlog item to allow a easier understanding and avoid the necessity to dive into Azure DevOps Server to catch the topic/context Sample feat/mas/248691/replace-timespan addresses the task Replace TimeSpan.FromXyz(#) with #.Xyz() is realized from Stefan dev/apm/convert-to-tree-structure doesn't belong to a backlog item (e.g. for a "spontaneous" work package)

wiki/Good_to_know.html.title: Good to know | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/Good_to_know.html.keywords: Good to know Table of Contents Frequently used CLI commands CLI commands for compilation, unit testing, Paket , Git Dependency Management some knowledge about dependency and package management Aspect Oriented Programming How the project is benefiting from AOP with PostSharp xUnit Knowledge around xUnit Benefits of Visual Studio Code How Visual Studio Code can be used to debug FAKE build scripts. Benefits of LINQPad How LINQPad can speed you up during development Frequently used CLI commands Hint: The following commands are supposed to be used inside a Git Bash or Developer Prompt for Visual Studio . Therefore they use forward slashes ( / ) or backward slashes ( \ ) for folder separation. So please use the right CLI environment to run the program. Recommendation: Use the Developer Prompt for Visual Studio for everything around compiling the codebase and the Git Bash for everything around versioning. Hint: All commands are treated as used from the project root folder (aka DevTree root folder). Compilation/Build msbuild .\src\Bvms.UiAutomation.sln /t:Restore msbuild .\src\Bvms.UiAutomation.sln Run unit tests Bash: ./packages/xunit.runner.console/tools/net472/xunit.console.exe ./src/ConfigClient.DomainModel/ConfigClient.DomainModel.Tests/bin/Debug/ConfigClient.DomainModel.Tests.dll ./packages/xunit.runner.console/tools/net472/xunit.console.exe ./src/UseCaseTests/UseCaseTests/bin/Debug/Bvms.UiAutomation.UseCaseTests.dll ./deploy/xunit.console.exe ./deploy/Bvms.UiAutomation.UseCaseTests.dll Command Prompt: .\packages\xunit.runner.console\tools\net472\xunit.console.exe .\src\ConfigClient.DomainModel\ConfigClient.DomainModel.Tests\bin\Debug\Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.DomainModel.Tests.dll .\packages\xunit.runner.console\tools\net472\xunit.console.exe .\src\UseCaseTests\UseCaseTests\bin\Debug\Bvms.UiAutomation.UseCaseTests.dll Paket install or update dependencies (after modifying central paket.dependencies or project specific paket.reference ) .paket/paket.exe install .paket/paket.exe restore Git Hint: Some of the following Git commands make use of aliases. Ensure that your personal .gitconfig contains these aliases. You can read more about the default configuration in the Baseline chapter of the Installation Guideline . show the status git st switch to branch; Create new branch and switch to it git co <branch-name> git co -b <new-branch-name> merge or rebase content of other branch in current branch Important: Use always the --ff-only option for a merge to avoid a 2-way merge! git merge <other-branch-name> --ff-only git rebase <new-branch-name> synchronization between local and remote repository git fetch --all git push git pull --ff-only Dependency Management dependency management is done with Paket (on top of NuGet ) References BVMS.wiki: Dependency Management With Paket Google Docs Presentation: Paket Paket Project Google Docs Presentation: NuGet Hint: Google Docs Presentations are currently not accessible from E-Net, but from BCN. Aspect Oriented Programming we use PostSharp for AOP it allows us to target the anti-pattern "Primitive Obsession" elegant, e.g. for range limited types XUnit Categories, Trait To group unit test in a way which makes sense for a project, the Attribute Trait is used. The following example puts the test method Can_Start_App under the category UI-Basics . [Theory, Trait("Category", "UI-Basics")] [InlineData(false)] public void Can_Start_App(bool closeAppAfterRun) ReSharper 's Unit Test Explorer ( Extensions > ReSharper > Windows > Unit Tests or Ctrl + Alt + U ) shows the method then under category UI-Basics and belonging class: InlineData and MemberData xUnit allows the definition of multiple input values for a test. Such parametrizable tests needs to have the attribute Theory . Test without parameters are setup as Fact . With InlineData the parameters of the text method are filled with the corresponding data of the InlineData definition: [Theory] [InlineData("1.1.1.1", DecoderType.BarcoMonitorWall)] [InlineData("223.255.255.255", DecoderType.VideoJetDecoder7000)] public void Can_add_and_configure_decoder_device(string deviceName, DecoderType decoderType) With MemberData it is possible to extract the test-data provider for better readability: [Theory] [MemberData(nameof(Data))] public void Can_switch_Panes(PaneTypeWithPaneName paneTypeWithPaneName) { ... public static IEnumerable<object[]> Data => new List<object[]> { new object[] { new PaneTypeWithPaneName(...) }, new object[] { new PaneTypeWithPaneName(...) }, ... Benefits of Visual Studio Code Debugging FAKE scripts Debugging FAKE scripts without a proper tool set can be a time consuming and annoying task. But VSC can be used as real IDE with debugging capabilities. see also Debugging of FAKE 5 build scripts Download fake-dotnetcore-portable.zip (e.g. from https://github.com/fsharp/FAKE/releases ) Extract the archive to the portable apps folder (e.g. c:\_apps\Tools\fake-dotnetcore-portable ) Open Visual Studio Code Click in the sidebar Extensions and install the following extensions: C# Ionide-fsharp Ionide-FAKE Ionide-Paket Click in the sidebar Debug expand configurations-combobox and choose Add Configuration in the list select dotnet core paste this configuration block directly inside the square brackets of the configuration key { "name": Debug Fake Script, "type": coreclr, "request": launch, "program": c:\_apps\Tools\fake-dotnetcore-portable\fake.dll, "args": [run, nocache, fsiargs, debug:portable optimize-, build.fsx], "cwd": ${workspaceRoot}, "stopAtEntry": false, "console": internalConsole } save the launch.json configuration file set breakpoints where wanted select in the configurations-combobox the new configuration Debug Fake Script and run this configuration Benefits of LINQPad LINQPad is a small utility to interactively writing C# code without the need for a heavyweight IDE. It comes in different edition where also the free edition give some benefits. But only the higher versions are really useful. With LINQPad it is much more faster to interact with an application which needs to get UI Automation driven. The most important fact is the almost infinite small compilation and startup time. Here are the steps to connect to the ConfigClient : Start the ConfigClient Start LINQPad Under Language select C# Program Press F4 to open dialog Query Properties where you can adjust some properties On tab Additional References click button Add NuGet... In new opened dialog LINQPad NuGet Manager search for FlaUI.UIA3 and add the package with button Add to Query and close the dialog with button Close . this should also add the package _ FlaUI Core . If not, add the package like the first package. On tab Additional Namespace Imports add some default namespaces, like FlaUI.UIA3 , FlaUI.Core , FlaUI.Core.AutomationElements and close with OK Use the script below as a example to interact with the ConfigClient void Main() { var processName = "ConfigClient"; var process = Process.GetProcesses().FirstOrDefault(p => p.ProcessName.Equals(processName)); var app = Application.Attach(process); using (var automation = new UIA3Automation()) { var window = app.GetMainWindow(automation); var toolbar = window.FindFirstDescendant("MainMenu : Toolbar"); var children = toolbar.FindAllChildren(); foreach (var element in children) { Console.WriteLine("element: " + element.Name); if (element.Name == "System") { element.Click(); } } } }
